no apparently they don't. i know i have been quiet the past few days. i am not feeling well but you know i stand behind you and this is the truth 100%. this is what is happening to us. we have asked for peace and quiet and we deserve it. they need to stop. we are done
it is....we are a problem for them
hope is true and we truly hope for a better tomorrow. thank you for speaking up.
thank you

i still remember the hours of hard labor with my first & it hurt like hell but i wouldn't give it up for the world. those intense moments, each contraction, each time i pushed....nope, too special to me. it hurts but it does come to an end; be present, the memories are priceless

i was present mentally and emotionally during my labors (17.5 hours, 12 and 5) and have wonderful memories of bringing my children into the world. no way would i trade that to sit there with that on my face, all to avoid an epidural (which i had with 2 of my 3 sons).

i just read that thing, take away labor pains? um, i have gone through 3 births, each one special and painful as anything and i wouldn't trade being present to feel every contraction, every time i screamed....wouldn't trade it for the world.

oh gosh....i think this would be great for kids undergoing a dental procedure or anyone if they are nervous prior to undergoing surgery but my goodness, i have things to do. i can't sit around all day with that on my head!
watch 's broadcast: putting a face on chronicpain why can't they fix their problems. who goes to painmangement
no and i am tired of the intentional mis-framing and the disruption of our work. we constantly are accused of what they are doing to us. i know who is behind this......

yeah it is funny....i agree. we are making headway, more united than ever. they want to stop that from happening. we are presenting research and the truth; that poses a problem as well so this is the expected response. they need to stop.
watch this..... watch 's broadcast: pnns attack on the pain community under the guise of “unity” it’s time to get real & stop playing these games.....
sometimes things aren’t what they seem. stay tuned for a live video from her  will explain. i will tweet it out when she starts.
i will  thank you for the fyi
aw......hey my friend. i am so happy we re-connected too. i hope you have a beautiful night and sleep well.
hey everyone....our favorite girl,  wrote something good here that i think we can all get behind. please take a read and sign.
don't mistake my activism for anger. i am not angry, i am motivated
watch 's broadcast: nurseproblems ernurse ednurse tiktoknurses pain is not funny nightnurses opioids take care of your patients

yeah i was afraid i was going to somehow rip it off. it was weird, i remember when i recorded this and i almost took it off subconsciously as i was worried i would rip the beautiful shawl that  made. plus i didn't want to lose the spoon! i would be sad!
thank you. i am glad you liked my words. they were meant to inspire and let everyone know, we all have a voice and a right to use it.
yes it sure is! i have it nice and safe in my jewelry box. very symbolic and cute
oh my goodness.....

that is the saddest part is those of us who put so much hope and trust in some of these people and then we find out...things weren't what they seemed. answer me this, does she hang out and chat with us anymore? i wouldn't know, i am curious
yeah psych and self management. no thank you.

this is never to discount someone who wants to take buprenorphine and go to therapy in my heart. it's all what is best for you but what is best for me and what is best for many of us and future patients is to have the ability to have mu agonist opioids available

i honestly don't either. it's whatever the person needs, you know? but if you read that report, there is no way, this was not about us being in a position to keep our opiate access. they say it is but imo the report says otherwise.
we do and we have to stop this no pain act and all that is coming with it. there is some stuff buried in there and then the hhs pmtf, the studies...all of it. i want my individualized care back

it seems like the stigma grows day after day. why the heck are we second class citizens? they placed a moral value on my need for pain relief. my medication has nothing to do with morality. it has to do with my ability to live.

that is the issue as i see it. entering into a community and knowing that desperate people needing help think you are going to save the day and then to find out that the idea of help is psychological treatments and buprenorphine? no thanks. i want opiate pain medication access
which one? the original article?
yes i saw that too.
yes we do.
i don't know if it is an error and i am sure the concern showed about abandonment is real.
thank you
oh wait, i see someone below did. my bad. sorry i’ve been gone for a few days
i think it’s in the document. the hhs pmtd one. i’m leaving the house. when i get back i can post it
https://www.hhs.gov/sites/default/files/pmtf-final-report-2019-05-23.pdf it should be in there. sorry i just caught myself sleeping and i can barely think straight. if you can't find it, let me know
the pmtf report. the authors should be listed in there. let me grab it
we do
yeah it is.
i love how they throw in a bone saying our data is “secure”. no...i want to be alone in the room with my doctor and don’t want them in there influencing my treatment.

of course it is! i can’t wait to clear my plate and look. i just fell asleep 15 minutes ago tweeting. sitting up. yeah it’s our data. i don’t want to be in these studies anymore. i’m tired of others making money off my bad fortune
oh i should say, we can have bdsi’s b products of course. those are “opiates” with a twist

well unfortunately from what i’ve been digging up; it’s just my opinion, she wasn’t going to help us maintain access to opiates. there’s too much here pointing elsewhere. she perhaps believes she’s doing the right thing for all i know but this kinda stuff doesn’t happen overnight

it appears those invested in promoting the opiate crisis as a rx issue are concerned that covid has taken center stage. i’ve been watching & seems there’s a push to tell all the opiate crisis is getting worse! it was never about rx opiates and always illicit drug users.

we painful disease patients are being blamed (yes blamed) for “driving” the “raging” opiate crisis. apparently vanila singh is going to speak (or spoke) and the hhs pain mgmt task force report will save the day! illicit drugs users caused this. not us http://www.ihpc.org/the-congressional-integrative-health-and-wellness-caucus/

we should be able to stand up & say that we want to be as pain free as we can & if opiate pain medication helps us achieve that status, then so be it. i’m tired of feeling like we can’t say this there is no shame in being honest & anyone who says otherwise is disingenuous
and i meant to say, you’re welcome. hang in there . sorry i had no manners in my response.

that’s so awful. think about it, he quit you? more like he let you down and walked. they need to do something about this and i don’t mean self management. they need to make it safe for doctors to practice again.

hey yeah i’ve seen bits and pieces. i’m not able to watch much or be online. i’m working on something so as soon as i’m done, i have some catching up to do. thanks for making sure i saw. pretty outrageous stuff isn’t it?

oh goodness i’m so sorry you’ve been turned away 3 times. that’s horrible. so much for “patient centered” care. we need real help, real care and fast. this has to stop. they’re going to see that this isn’t going to work for many of us. i’m sorry. hang in there

well from this area it appears it’s mostly about studying our community and creating more guidelines! forcing us into alternatives to study the results. data will be generated. a win win for everyone except us. we pay 4 insurance & lose our freedom of choice, privacy & autonomy
i wish....covid has been an issue. as soon as we can travel, we will

hey; you need to read this. if you have not read the hhs pmtf report, if you are just taking my word 4 it, then are denying yourself the privilege of choice of knowing what this says and what will happen to you if you don't speak up now. read this & fight http://uploads.documents.cimpress.io/v1/uploads/84ead595-328c-4e20-b0cc-d45b1236ac2f~110/original?tenant=vbu-digital
thank you! i appreciate it very much
thanks girl! i'm looking forward to doing really cool things on our channel together.

the hhs pmtf report calls for more guidelines. a guideline for every pain condition. tell me how that is "individualized" care? the best part; they need to do more research to get the data to create the guidelines! talk about blatantly studying the public.

yes it really is and it is going to hurt a lot of people. they are calling it "individualized care" and it is nothing of the sort. if you read it, you will find that they want a guideline for everything. tell me, how is applying a guideline "individualized" care?

twitterstorm help us speak out against the hhs pmtf report by tweeting  and  who got this into the 2021 appropriations bill. we need to tell them that it needs to be removed! we created this info graph that points out the issues http://uploads.documents.cimpress.io/v1/uploads/84ead595-328c-4e20-b0cc-d45b1236ac2f~110/original?tenant=vbu-digital
thank you for saying that. lauren and i would gladly represent and speak.
oh heather, that makes me so sad for you and him. i am sorry

oh no! that must have been so hard to go thru! an infection where the pump was implanted? that is the thing, if you can get relief from a proper dose of oral meds then why put you thru that? i am sorry you had to endure that. it needs to end.
yes we are!!!!

thank you! the effort is really appreciated and we are trying to make this as easy as possible for everyone who is against this and does want to send an email. thank you so much for all you do. i have seen you step up to assist many times. you rock!

myra christopher speaks after von korff & acknowledges the number is really at least 116 million & that is consistent with other countries that are comparable to the us. she then says, "until the iom says it, it's not true". (iom is now nam & is a 501c3)

he says "eyes start to roll" when one says "100 million" and says you make the "message more powerful" when people "can believe it". von korff (prop) stands up and says it came from a study that he was the "2nd author on" and that he really doesn't like the number after all.

if you listen to this short 6 minute video below, you will learn where the other 50 million went this is video of the iprcc (essentially the authors of the national pain strategy) watch to learn how to get rid of 50 million people in the course of 1 hour

ah yes, back when there was 100 million of us. now there is apparently only 50 million. where did the other 50 million go? i know, i know; they re-categorized but really, the other 50 million who aren't being accounted for, deserve to be noticed. they didn't just disappear

i am so sorry that stronger medications have failed you. i really really hope that you are able to find some combination of something to help. whether it's pharmaceutical or not, just something to make you feel better. no one should have to suffer. i hope you can get some relief

so many of us have tried and failed all these "nice" sounding "safe" alternatives. what they refuse to accept is opiates are safe for the vast majority of us! they make their arguments about safety yet the rate of adxn is so low that opiates are safe for the vast majority of us

i know! i can spot a few things on there that are definitely problematic and it isn't opioids! actually, scratch that; it is problematic that only short term opioids are acknowledged. many of us have tried lots of these things,they don't work & we need access long term opiates!

you've got it! here's a fun screenshot. notice how it specifies "short term opioid" last. i know, it says it's in no "specified order" but c'mon. when i hear ppl say this report is about "individualized care" therefore, that means we get ltot, i don't buy it for a second

calling it "patient centered" doesn't make it so. we had individualized care before when the dr was allowed to take care of the patient in front of him/her. the national pain strategy is being implemented via this report & your care will be based on what's best for the population

remember this report will ensure that the patient engages in different non-opiate, complementary/alternative strategies before they are eligible to get an opiate and when they do, they get buprenorphine! (then from pg 33 of the report)

good morning! we need help from everyone. the hhs pain management task force report is one step closer to becoming the "cookie cutter" standard of care. please read the email  and i wrote and help us put a stop to this. http://9thx.mjt.lu/nl2/9thx/5r0hh.html?hl=en
i fell in love with video editing. i hope to get more time soon to make more interesting and entertaining things for us to enjoy.

exactly and she felt nice and safe in her little meeting to speak her mind. well, these zealots are going to learn, i will find your video and we will find it and watch. they need to be held responsible for their cruelty and discrimination. how dare she call us couch potatoes.
she’s pretty mean. i’m sure the other meds would be fine. she clearly said opiates make us couch potatoes. totally obscene.
omg thank you! i know there’s humor in there but we deserve a break from the seriousness and she did say what she said
thank you! i’m glad you enjoyed it. i want to do a series of these with our favorite anti opioid crowd on tape. we deserve a good laugh while hearing about what they say
she’s pretty mean.....
aw....c’mon! you’ll get a good laugh out of it
i can’t tell you how you warned me and then i experienced it for myself. so yeah....good times

its amazing to see what the anti opiate crowd says when they are in their meetings with colleagues. i wonder if dr ballentyne would’ve called us “couch potatoes” had we been present. this is a short 2 minute video. take a look!

well, after much technical difficulty, i figured out that i needed to post this on my youtube channel. come and see how jane ballentyne talks about chronic illness patients who need to take opiates to deal with their pain. it's a 2 minute video. enjoy https://youtu.be/4xqjffz2tri

it's disappointing but i am hoping that it was recorded. i think most people these days are using zoom and that has a record feature so.....fingers crossed! it's nice to see you and i hope you are doing well. loving my ring!
hi! i haven’t seen you in what feels like months! yes, we signed up and neither of us got our sign on info. so yes.

it is frustrating however, we as a community are starting to figure this all out and it won't be long before it is common knowledge and they will have to level the playing field. i suspect what is going on will be evident to all very soon.
i guess a good question would be....who was in attendance?
and in news articles, on committees, at meetings....always the first to know

i would really appreciate it. thank you very much. we would've liked to attend. i am hoping since so many meetings are happening via zoom these days and zoom has the capability to record that there will be a copy we could watch.

and i both signed up to attend this meeting and strangely enough, neither of us received an invite & i know mistakes happen. this person states they heard "0 pain patients were on the meeting". that's disappointing as it concerns us and our care. disappointed

sure doesn't sound "patient centered" to me. this is why we are pointing out, all the things coming from the nih, the national pain strategy, stanford; all of it....it isn't "patient centered", it is population focused and we are done. we want our healthcare back!
you're welcome! i had fun making it. i wonder if this means i can make short videos on fcpx and download them straight to twitter without going thru youtube? hmmm.....i have an idea.......
.....you matter to me

i am so proud of my friend and partner  that i made this short little video to remind everyone that endorsements/nominations are still open for the  awards! please visit our website at http://www.ciaag.net to show your support in endorsing her.
i pray i never have to go thru that again. no human being should have to endure that type of suffering. anyone who thinks they should is sadistic and cruel
and i meant to say, "you're welcome"!

i didn't perceive you as cynical at all! in fact, you seemed quite friendly. yours is arthritic and mine is muscle inflammation, it would seem that reaching a muscle thru the skin would be easier than the joint. i wouldn't know but i do hope you can find something that helps you

yes me too! i was using it 12 years ago and getting samples from my dr because it was so expensive but it really did help. i am sorry your disease prevents you from taking nsaids but am happy you can get voltaren.
they most certainly do. they can hurt, they can help.

oh nice! that sounds good. i am glad you had those....i love crab legs! i haven't had crab legs since right before covid hit. oh that sounds wonderful. i think i have a good dinner suggestion for my husband.

even if we had "unlimited" pain meds, we wouldn't abuse it! that's the 1st thing that crossed my mind why is there moral judgement cast upon the person who dares to say they want their pain relieved w/opiates? is it moral & good to say "i will do without"? no, i think its foolish

the major thing that hurts our community is when people try to shame us for standing up and saying we want our pain relieved & we want our medication to relieve that pain. it was decided we had to promote alternatives in order to maintain credibility and that just isn't the case

no one here has ever asked for unlimited pain medication. this is the message that is put out to counter what we are saying to try (& yet again) get people to not follow what we are promoting and silence us. it is not true and we all know that. no one has ever said such a thing

i have a rare autoimmune disease called dermatomyositis. every bone, muscle, joint, everything hurts so incredibly bad, head to toe especially back then. i was undiagnosed at the time. it's all over body inflammation. at the time, my ribs hurt and that is what was waking me up

this was the only thing i had before i was given proper relief. i used to wake up crying every night at 3 am and my husband would have to rub this literally all over my body. it helped but the hell i went through for 3.5 years before opioids-i never want to go thru that again.

oh geez, you know...just ignore them. there are plenty of really nice people here. as long as you aren't following them, they will go into an area in the dm and you don't have to accept the message. i have had to tell guys i am married and they still persist. just ignore them
it takes all our voices to make change don't ever let anyone take your voice or make you feel like you need someone to speak for you. yourvoicematters
that is so true and beautifully stated retweet!

it can be called "individualized care" all they want but we know what it is....it's population health strategies which is the furthest thing from individualized care that you can get. it isn't about what benefits you, it is about what is best for society.

yes yes yes!!!!!! that is the thing and this implication that there are others that "know more" than we do or that we just don't "understand" that rhetoric is being used to silence the voices that may be just getting the courage to speak out. i don't like to see that!

the one thing i have learned through all of this is....they mean what they say. in other words, what is written in these reports is what is going to happen. the reports written at the nam, those are used to dictate policy. what is written is what happens.

all this pain strategy stuff is the furthest thing from individualized care i have ever seen. we used to have individualized care before the intrusion into our medical records/care. just because they call it something doesn't make it so. we want individualized care back.

that is what is so upsetting. now when we point out the work these advocates are promoting, it doesn't seem to align with what we were led to believe. when we ask, we are told we don't understand. no, we do understand. we understand very well.

interestingly enough, the iprcc had prop members in their groups so when they were creating the national pain strategy, they were there. david tauben, michael von korff existing side by side with some of the advocates that were supposed to be looking out for us.
my goal is to encourage everyone to use their voice, not to sit back, be complacent and allow someone else to speak. we were each given our own voice and i want to inspire others to use it!

that is the thing. it is one thing to have a unified message but to say that we all need to sit down and be quiet and let one person speak for all of us? i don't think so. we all have our own voices that we can use.

i counted how many times buprenorphine is mentioned in the report....i think i may have counted over 50. i have to count again to refresh my memory. it was a lot. it’s clear what they’re doing behind the protected saying of “individualized care”. it’s not individualized at all
(insert standing ovation)

they are the first ones to jump into a perfectly good conversation where no one is even discussing the one voice concept and they begin to systematically break the momentum of the conversation, forcing their opinions, listening to no one and persisting until disharmony erupts
what in the heck......omg. ok, i am going to go and look into this. thank you for sending this my way. thank you.
my husband is a good cook!
what you had sounds really good! nice, glad to hear others ate well tonight too

thank you for letting us know. he’s exhibiting really disturbing behavior. i’m sorry his family member had problems but to take it out on painful disease patients is unacceptable. i’m sure his family member wouldn’t approve and would be saddened by this.
for anyone who can’t see the retweeted tweet......
that sounds good! i would love to see what you guys are going to have for breakfast. crepes sound wonderful and you have some nice sounding fruit.....mmmmmmm

what is scientific about being told that you’re overexagerating an irrational thought about your real physical symptoms? renaming the word won’t change the definition behind it. the term “catastrophizing” needs to go https://twitter.com/drseanmackey/status/1276697773182554112
whoo hoo! love our chicken dancers!!!! now this is one i hadn't seen before. omg thank you for making me smile
husband comes home from working all day and he just cooked & served this to me! wow! talk about a lucky girl. anybody else eating anything good/special tonight?
and honestly, if you need to treat people like that to have a "seat".....then i would rather sit on the floor. i can speak my mind from there.
my answer to everything! where's my chicken boy!!!

is this a new study? i have to go and look this up. i hadn't heard of this before but i am not surprised as i haven't been able to research like i used to in awhile. thank you for sharing this. i am going to look into it.

you know what just occurred 2 me? you were probably one of the 1st people to read the report & see what was in there so when you came out with information, it was easier 4 them to push back on you. my hope is we as a community can start reading more so we can support each other

yeah. exhausting, isn't it? i mean, we have shown over and over again, this isn't happening and honestly, it is to the point with so many who are taking their own lives from untreated pain....this guy needs someone to work with him to educate him. he needs to learn the truth
oh for goodness sakes. are we really still having to see this type of talk? smdh......really really smdh.
oh wow so in other words...a person would need to add in amed to counteract the effects of the other, right?

to tell someone for expressing their ideas that they are single-handedly responsible for preventing an official or md from working with us; that is mean and prevents others from ever using their voice as they fear it will happen to them. to me that is the true cause of division

we do and i was thinking that somewhere along the way, it became "wrong" to be able to be free to say that. i asked myself, what is so wrong with saying, i just want to take my medication and be done with it? it was turned into something i should feel shame for; but why?

then in my mind, that way of thinking is a different community. i suspect that is how we as a community got in this position in the first place by conceding, giving up, being afraid to speak out against what we were told we had to be quiet about. happened with the darnall issue

i know how you feel. i really do. it's not a good feeling and everyone wants to be liked but i realized....anyone that doesn't like me for what i have to say or how i choose to advocate....they weren't my friends in the first place.

there is nothing wrong with speaking your mind. in fact, it took me a long time before i felt comfortable really speaking out. it does take some bravery and i think more would do it if they didn't see others put down for doing it. i learned this last year, i have to speak up

getting a seat at "the big kids table" is what my mom would say to me when i was 5 at holiday time. we get a chance to participate in the discussion when we bring forth truth, facts & determination in what we believe. no one should be shaming another into silence for speaking up

in fact, if someone wants to work with our community, they will. they aren't going to go thru the threads and say, "you know, i was going to help this community but i don't like what shasta is saying today so they can all suffer....i changed my mind". it's hogwash

oh that is not ok and totally unfair. this business about our conversations and speaking out being mis-framed as a reason that md's and policymakers don't want to work with us, i honestly believe that is to silence us because what they are saying is 100% right on!

imo there is a hyper focus on turning physical diagnoses into psych ones. we have physical issues and they hurt! just because they may not be able to see it with their own eyes, doesn't mean it's not there. pain is what the patient says it is....period, dot.
that is really cool to know! thank you for sharing that with me. my husband just literally walked in the door and i can't wait to tell him what you said. thank you!!!

i don't understand why people can't advocate for alternative treatments to be covered by cms without having to promote this idea that cpp's on ltot are part of the od/addiction crisis. we have proven time and time again that it is illicit drugs that are causing the od's

so true. the alliance for complementary & integrative pm group is saying (screenshot below. imo, it really leads the reader to conclude that again, cpp's taking opioids for pain are a part of the cause of the od crisis and we know that is not true! https://morningconsult.com/opinions/combating-opioid-overdose-crisis-alleviating-chronic-pain/

we are accused of "dividing" the community for sharing information. it's frustrating and it has to stop. in my eyes, that is the type of action that creates division. it leaves the person feeling like everyone has turned their back on them when all they wanted to do was share.

what i don't understand is that when we point out what the report says, we become "problematic". i will never understand that. being bullied for discussing the truth is a tactic used to silence us. if this report is so great, why can't we discuss it? we are educating ourselves

what i don't understand is if these individuals believe in what they are doing and think it is the right thing, then why is there any push back at all when we discuss it? they should be proud of their work, right?

i have seen you use this phrase before, "upper echelon advocates" and i know what you mean by that but honestly, no one is better than anyone else. we are all the same and anyone who puts themselves on a pedestal like that, is not advocating.

you should have never been mistreated for sharing that information that you learned about dr singh. i had seen this happen enough times that i had to speak up. it's not right that we are just expected to be silent observers and accept our fate.
hey guys.... was nominated for 2 more awards! even if you already endorsed her, you can still go and endorse her for the 2 new nominations! let's show her some support!!!!
why do we have more than one community......join us and find out why
yeah i have no idea. i was kinda surprised. it’s ok.
this is a first. my husband cut into a red pepper. look what he found! i had never seen this before. i will take this as a sign of good things to come.

i suspect it's a way to deter people in the community from advocating for access to opioids to focus on advocating for the alt tx's. there's not a single person in this community since i joined in 2017 that ever stated that they wanted unlimited/unrestricted access to opioids

i agree with you. i am glad i didn't respond. it isn't worth it but it's disappointing. i am so ready to get back to research and making videos i enjoy what i do and our community. i will continue to focus on that. i hope you have a good night. it's time to turn in

the documentation in this report is all verified. please look at the citations in the back and you will see. http://uploads.documents.cimpress.io/v1/uploads/c7c18e1c-2c3d-4ffd-b251-2ddba53a2d8b~110/original?tenant=vbu-digital
this one will show you that we are in a human clinical trial. no one was told. here's the documentation. https://www.iprcc.nih.gov/sites/default/files/nps_implementationwebinarsummary_508c.pdf
this one is about the no pain act, legislation, pacira, voices for non opioid choices....this is one i need to follow up on

https://www.pscp.tv/shasta77777/1ynxapydnmdjj this was when i found the paperwork at the nih and meeting notes. this solidified violation of a nation and is solid evidence that they knew we were going to be harmed. if you watch nothing else...this one is the one to watch
bunavail, buprenorphine and vanila singh
i downloaded the book by alinsky. i have a feeling i might learn a lot from it

you owe no one an explanation. the people that appreciate you and value you as a person and fellow advocate know that. this is clearly someone who has problems and is not intending to work anything out. she is trying to hurt you. she isn't worth it. i am sorry

it's not very often someone says to me, "i don't know who or what you are". this is a new kind of....i don't know what. last time i checked, i am a human being. there is no room for this type of bullying and cruelty online.

"what" i am? well, i am a human being for starters & i wanted to try and help so there is no reason to be hostile. i am not anyone special, just someone online you are following. i thought i saw an opportunity to help and if this was about my work, wanted to assist.

just to clarify, she didn't bring me into this conversation (i saw your comment and you're telling her not to bring others into the conversation). this showed up in my notifications & i felt compelled to help. all the ppl this got forwarded to, are part of the conversation

if you are referring to lauren & i, please don't hesitate to reach out to us. we are happy to help. if i am responding to you in error, please excuse me & i do not mean to interrupt but the way the thread is reading, this seems to have something to do with my report.

in fact, i recall when you called me and you asked my permission to use violation of a nation to present. i told you it was public and anyone could use it but that i appreciated your consideration and that you could use it with my blessing and i hope that it helped
you have been nothing but honest, forthcoming and kind. for anyone to state otherwise is completely off base and means they don't know you very well.

delorse....you have never been anything but honest and forthcoming and have treated our work with respect. i have no idea who this person is, but if she is talking about violation of a nation, then i would be happy address that.
i believe that delorse was using violation of a nation and i am one of the 2 authors of that report. she asked me if she could use it and i said "yes". i hope you are not referring to my report.
thomas mcclellan, now he was on the ondcp and is on shatterproof. apparently there has been some issues that came up and i talk about it. he is a high up govt official
the national pain strategy....some info on that
the guidelines and the ahrq
complex persistent dependence....not a nice term

in case anyone is wondering, i am not an investor. i am a married, disabled mother of 3 with a serious illness that is progressive with no cure. i do what i can to the best of my ability but unfortunately, can't do as good of a job as i want because of my physical limitations.

we are put down, criticized, called names, others attempts to discredit our hard work and we have to take it yet are criticized when we speak out against it/stand up for ourselves. to me that’s not creating division, it’s standing up for what’s right-what we believe in

how is it petty to stand by what you believe and fight for the rights that you want to preserve? i guess it’s only a problem when it has the potential to disrupt what another is trying to promote; when our message is a detriment to someone else achieving their goals.

there’s no rivalry here. those of us working for access to pain medicine, are supportive of one another, don’t go to others threads to attempt to discredit their work (while it’s actively happening to us). we mind our own & teach yet are framed as the “problem”.

after reading it i was left with the feeling that this was to promote the groups that are in support of the nps (includes the hhs pmtf best practices report) and that if we don’t, we are a problem, we are divisive. i’m not saying this was his goal but it was my impression

i found it to be apropos as well. it’s clear to me, we have 3 different advocacy strategies/groups/schools of thought at play here in the “pain community”. i do not see division amongst those of us who are working for access to pain medication. we are more unified than ever

i’m glad you’re able to see your pcp. i’ve worked with quite a few amazing pcp’s. you’re lucky to have one who is able to care for you. seems many do well with their pcp. it is nice to keep things close to home as they say. you know, see the same person for most of your needs

imagine my shock years later to see this and my experience tells me otherwise! i did float around to other offices for a few years. i charted the rx’s, saw everything that went on. no one dr shopped & there was no overprescribing! everything was fine! pain care was good for most

then i got sick in 2009 so my careeer was over and i became a cpp. i was there when all this supposed “overprescribing” happened. i worked in a very busy office. there was no overprescribing. in fact, most rx’s fell within the cdc gl’s, start low, go slow, etc

the thing is, pcp’s we’re able to monitor their patients & rx opiates safely. there was the occasional patient & let me tell you, the pharmacists, us cma’s, the other dr offices; we all knew each other. no patient got away with anything funny. not many tried. this was 2003-2008

our pcp’s did a good job with many of us. somewhere along the line, this idea that pcp’s don’t know how to treat pain came up. i worked for quite a few years as a cma so i saw what went on with our cpp’s. many of them were able to keep working, care for their families and had qol

this is where it gets interesting. here you can see, it was a question that was posed, asking at what dose they thought patients start doing poorly. he states there was no guidelines or parameters so they took their best guess...80mme
was that just his opinion or was it fact?

dr tauben was the co-chair of the opioid prescribing guideline committee who was tasked with developing opioid prescribing guidelines and that is when the question of opioid dose limits was brought up. he stated that there was an "over reliance" on opioids in clinical practice
he proudly chanted at the end of one of his presentations, "no more opioids" and the whole room erupted in applause. he served as an "expert" over at the cdc

remember, dr tauben was the dr who was at the pain care for primary care conference in san francisco back in november 2017 that proudly stated on a stage in my presence that where he works, their goal was to get their cpp's on ltot transitioned onto buprenorphine
we've all heard the story of how the 90mme made its way into our lives via the cdc guidelines but check this out....it appears it was the work of u of wa/ prop's own dr tauben & co.!

here's a nice view of one of the still parts of the river by my house. it is so peaceful here. typically i like nymphing in the white water but whenever there is a little hatch going on (or heck, a big hatch), it is spots like this that are a heck of a lot of fun.
now i am going thru all my fishing pics. i might be able to go in a couple weeks. even with social distancing, this is something we can still do; enjoy the outdoors. heck, it is good for us.

oh my! my tippet is typically 5-7 lb test...i have 2 rods, one a 4 wt and a 5wt. wow, what a difference. we have a good river here for steelhead and it is a big thing up here but i go north for the rainbows...i am going to have to try it someday. just have to! looks like fun

what a great pic! i love it!!!! you look happy & to me, that's so important. they want patients with painful diseases out & about engaging in positive activities..well, here ya go! we need some relief to do so. let us use our pain medicine and we will enjoy days like this

that for sure is hard on the shoulder. the fish you catch are way heavier than the ones i do and i struggle enough netting a little 10" rainbow. the current feels like it adds 20 lbs easy. i have yet to try steelhead, it's a different technique but i want to try

we have mostly rainbow trout in the river i fish and they are so much fun to play. even a little 10" fish can be the strongest little thing as they can put a nice bend in my rod as i try and land them. letting them take a little line, knowing i will set them free when it's over

what is your favorite fish to catch? do you fly fish, bait fish or both? fly fising is the love of my life; it's what keeps me going. i always enjoy meeting other hard core fishermen i can't wait to get out on the water this year hoping for an amazing season!

what is patient centered care to you?

this is what i call "patient centered care" and important to note: most people would be happy to help these pain studies but the problem was no one asked. our treatment was changed & we were studied without our consent. that is not how this is supposed to work. ask next time

patient centered care is: not shrouding the unknown in phrases like "best practices" when it's unknown if these practices are what's "best". it is not gaslighting me & telling me i am not trying hard enough & calling me a drug seeker if i want a pain rx instead of mindfulness

patient centered care is: being aware that these activities are occurring and having the ability to say "no; i want my doctors visit to be about me, what is best for me, what will help me have the best chance of leading my best life while using treatments i approve of; prefer"

patient centered care is: care that is based on my needs, not the needs of the population or whatever study is happening in my area. i'm sorry there are ppl who struggle with respecting the medication i use to treat my painful disease. i need this medication to function/live

patient centered care is: not needing to justify (to anyone) my right for wanting to have a private relationship w/my dr that doesn't involve academic institutions, grant money, overzealous pharmacists & insurance company employees who have no medical degree yet dictate my care

patient centered care is: being able to "just say no" to being forced into giving up my medication while simultaneously being forced to perform unproven treatments such as mindfulness & tai chi so principle investigators can study my outcomes while calling it "best practices"

patient centered care is: having the ability to "just say no" to sharing my pdmp data, my family's medical history, my medical history, medical records & pdmp data with an unknown principle investigator...who wants data for a study

patient centered care is: having the ability to know if my medical information is being shared for the purposes of a study & knowing if my treatment options are being effected by a principle investigator determining what my treatment will be so they can get the data they want

patient centered care is: the right to know if a principle investigator selected me to unknowingly participate in a study while sharing my dr's appointments, health issues & treatment outcomes via the emr to capture my data & study my experiences/outcomes w/o my knowledge

the "collaborative health outcomes information registry" (choir) was created by mackey & his team. now, patient data/information could be gathered and used. mackey said there was a need for a "patient centered" system. is this "patient centered" or "research centered"?

the researchers could study the patients if the experiment was embedded into the care plan (the dr's visit). various treatments were then "incentivized" so they would be prescribed. now, they could study the patient outcomes & use the data to develop "evidence based" practices
the electronic medical record would be used to capture the data so that it could be used in the pain research.

a new term was introduced: "high impact chronic pain" that would distinguish patients who were self managing their pain from those mackey termed "high utilizers" which were those who were utilizing a large amount of resources to manage their pain.

the nps is a population research strategy; however, dr mackey noted that the available data on pain is considered to be of "poor quality". the population research group proposed a new set of objectives that would be undertaken in order to accomplish the goals of studying pain
the link takes us to this article, "the national pain strategy; a roadmap for effective pain care and management of chronic pain in america"

this article begins by discussing dr mackey's research and describes the focus and direction of the national pain strategy by providing us a link. it states that the goal was to improve pain care, management, research and education
here is an interesting article published by clinical pain advisor from may 25, 2016. it is about "the stanford pain management center; a successful model for chronic pain care"

oh that sounds enjoyable! i will have to check them out! my mind is so busy. i do a lot of reading/researching & i find my mind can't shut off thinking about all this opioid access stuff. i can't stop looking for answers so it does keep me up. i will try this! thank you!

i wanted it for intuitive reasons. it just seemed so....i don't know, cozy? i love small spaces and it seems weight on me would be soothing. this is a great invention. i hope others can try it if they are struggling. it helped with my autoimmune aches and sleepless nights.

i have to be honest, i never had heard of them for sleep issues & pain & i feel so darn lucky that i tried it. i am hoping this isn't just a chance occurrence. i haven't had good sleep for over 1.5 years (not because of pain). i was achy tonight & it helped soothe my muscles
thank goodness she grew out of it. i can only imagine how hard that was for you as a mom. 70 is pretty low. that would really scare me. glad she got bigger and it got better
yeah. it blows me away.

aw....she had a little achy face.....poor little thing with sinus infections. that must have broke your heart.

yes! it worked great for my boys and they would be so fussy with their fever and body aches. poor little guys.....i felt like i hit the jackpot when i figured this combo out to break the fever but...for my painful disease.....that isn't going to cut it

i am sorry you had a lifetime of pain. that is unfair and i know that it happens but it makes me sad for the younger people who have had to endure this. no one should have to endure pain if it can be relieved. no one.

that is so young. i consented to my son taking nsaids for an avulsion fracture from football at 13 yo. it tore his stomach up. it was horrible to watch him suffer. i would've preferred he take opioids which he did for his wisdom teeth and go figure...he had no issue with them

oh geez nick......i know that is the reality for many. it just shouldn't be like that. that is why we have opioids! for those who can't utilize the other meds! there is a reason why we have them and really, at this point you describe, they are absolutely safer.

when my kids were little & had fevers, i used to alternate tylenol & motrin to get it down & it helped. i'm not saying these meds don't have their place. this is probably a result of dr krebs (prop) & her junk science study that said tylenol & motrin work better than opioids

what a joke. how obscene. anyone knows you can supplement the medications on their own and omg....such a low dose! are they trying to force us into "self management". like this is a big breakthrough in pain management"? big joke!

i am so sorry. it is that type of deception that leads to people losing hope. there is none of that here. we have gone public with our stance so others can decide if they want to join us or not. no hard feelings if they feel differently. we just want the bullying to stop.
geez.....i am not surprised by anything anymore.

it stops today. no more. we are here to raise awareness and do great things. if you don't believe in access to opioids and want to focus on tapering, the nps and bupe, then you are in a different community and that is ok. just don't try to disrupt our work and go do yours.

i am so sorry that you are without the medication you need. that is not ok. i have always sensed you are a strong woman with a strong mind and will. they will not break you. for what it is worth, lauren and i support you and we will continue to fight this as best we can.

i understand and i feel the same way. i can be slow to really see things as i am focused on my work but when i started to see what was happening, i knew i had to speak up. there have to be others who are being bullied and suppressed by these people. it has to stop.

you have always been kind & supportive of lauren and i and we really really appreciate that. thank you & i hope that we now can all enjoy peace and quiet enjoyment on the internet. after our video, there is no question where we stand. i hope everyone will respect everyones wishes
